**Transcript**:
At roughly 4pm on July 20, 1969, mankind was just minutes away 
from landing on the surface of the moon. But before the astronauts 
began their final descent, an emergency alarm lit up. Something was overloading 
the computer, and threatened to abort the landing. Back on Earth, Margaret Hamilton 
held her breath. She'd led the team developing 
the pioneering in-flight software, so she knew this mission 
had no room for error. But the nature 
of this last-second emergency would soon prove her software 
was working exactly as planned. Born 33 years earlier in Paoli, Indiana, 
Hamilton had always been inquisitive. In college, she studied mathematics
and philosophy, before taking a research position at the 
Massachusetts Institute of Technology to pay for grad school. Here, she encountered her first computer
while developing software to support research 
into the new field of chaos theory. Next at MIT's Lincoln Laboratory, Hamilton developed software 
for America’s first air defense system to search for enemy aircraft. But when she heard 
that renowned engineer Charles Draper was looking for help 
sending mankind to the moon, she immediately joined his team. NASA looked to Draper and his group 
of over 400 engineers to invent the first compact 
digital flight computer, the Apollo Guidance Computer. Using input from astronauts, this device would be responsible 
for guiding, navigating and controlling the spacecraft. At a time when unreliable computers 
filled entire rooms, the AGC needed to operate 
without any errors, and fit in one cubic foot of space. Draper divided the lab into two teams, one for designing hardware 
and one for developing software. Hamilton led the team that built 
the on-board flight software for both the Command and Lunar Modules. This work, for which she coined the term
“software engineering," was incredibly high stakes. Human lives were on the line, 
so every program had to be perfect. Margaret’s software needed to quickly
detect unexpected errors and recover from them in real time. But this kind of adaptable program 
was difficult to build, since early software could only process 
jobs in a predetermined order. To solve this problem, Margaret designed her program 
to be “asynchronous,” meaning the software's more important
jobs would interrupt less important ones. Her team assigned every task 
a unique priority to ensure that each job 
occurred in the correct order and at the right time—
regardless of any surprises. After this breakthrough, Margaret realized her software 
could help the astronauts work in an asynchronous environment as well. She designed Priority Displays that would interrupt 
astronaut’s regularly scheduled tasks to warn them of emergencies. The astronaut could then communicate
with Mission Control to determine the best path forward. This marked the first time flight software
communicated directly— and asynchronously— 
with a pilot. It was these fail safes that triggered 
the alarms just before the lunar landing. Buzz Aldrin quickly realized his mistake— he’d inadvertently flipped 
the rendezvous radar switch. This radar would be essential 
on their journey home, but here it was using up 
vital computational resources. Fortunately, the Apollo Guidance Computer
was well equipped to manage this. During the overload, 
the software restart programs allowed only the highest priority jobs 
to be processed— including the programs 
necessary for landing. The Priority Displays 
gave the astronauts a choice— to land or not to land. With minutes to spare, 
Mission Control gave the order. The Apollo 11 landing was about 
the astronauts, Mission Control, software and hardware all working together
as an integrated system of systems. Hamilton’s contributions were essential
to the work of engineers and scientists inspired by President John F. Kennedy’s 
goal to reach the Moon. And her life-saving work 
went far beyond Apollo 11— no bugs were ever found in the in-flight
software for any crewed Apollo missions. After her work on Apollo, Hamilton founded a company that uses 
its unique universal systems language to create breakthroughs 
for systems and software. In 2003, NASA honored her achievements 
with the largest financial award they’d ever given to an individual. And 47 years after her software
first guided astronauts to the moon, Hamilton was awarded 
the Presidential Medal of Freedom for changing the way we think 
about technology.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Margaret’s computer software had to be __________, meaning the software’s more important jobs could interrupt less important ones.

Correct Option: A

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5: 

"What concept, developed by Margaret Hamilton's team, allowed the Apollo Guidance Computer to manage multiple tasks simultaneously? 
Options: A. Synchronous programming, B. Asynchronous programming, C. Parallel processing, D. Multitasking 
Correct Option: B"

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At roughly 4pm on July 20, 1969, mankind was just minutes away 
from landing on the surface of the moon. But before the astronauts 
began their final descent, an emergency alarm lit up. Something was overloading 
the computer, and threatened to abort the landing. Back on Earth, Margaret Hamilton 
held her breath. She'd led the team developing 
the pioneering in-flight software, so she knew this mission 
had no room for error. But the nature 
of this last-second emergency would soon prove her software 
was working exactly as planned. Born 33 years earlier in Paoli, Indiana, 
Hamilton had always been inquisitive. In college, she studied mathematics
and philosophy, before taking a research position at the 
Massachusetts Institute of Technology to pay for grad school. Here, she encountered her first computer
while developing software to support research 
into the new field of chaos theory. Next at MIT's Lincoln Laboratory, Hamilton developed software 
for America’s first air defense system to search for enemy aircraft. But when she heard 
that renowned engineer Charles Draper was looking for help 
sending mankind to the moon, she immediately joined his team. NASA looked to Draper and his group 
of over 400 engineers to invent the first compact 
digital flight computer, the Apollo Guidance Computer. Using input from astronauts, this device would be responsible 
for guiding, navigating and controlling the spacecraft. At a time when unreliable computers 
filled entire rooms, the AGC needed to operate 
without any errors, and fit in one cubic foot of space. Draper divided the lab into two teams, one for designing hardware 
and one for developing software. Hamilton led the team that built 
the on-board flight software for both the Command and Lunar Modules. This work, for which she coined the term
“software engineering," was incredibly high stakes. Human lives were on the line, 
so every program had to be perfect. Margaret’s software needed to quickly
detect unexpected errors and recover from them in real time. But this kind of adaptable program 
was difficult to build, since early software could only process 
jobs in a predetermined order. To solve this problem, Margaret designed her program 
to be “asynchronous,” meaning the software's more important
jobs would interrupt less important ones. Her team assigned every task 
a unique priority to ensure that each job 
occurred in the correct order and at the right time—
regardless of any surprises. After this breakthrough, Margaret realized her software 
could help the astronauts work in an asynchronous environment as well. She designed Priority Displays that would interrupt 
astronaut’s regularly scheduled tasks to warn them of emergencies. The astronaut could then communicate
with Mission Control to determine the best path forward. This marked the first time flight software
communicated directly— and asynchronously— 
with a pilot. It was these fail safes that triggered 
the alarms just before the lunar landing. Buzz Aldrin quickly realized his mistake— he’d inadvertently flipped 
the rendezvous radar switch. This radar would be essential 
on their journey home, but here it was using up 
vital computational resources. Fortunately, the Apollo Guidance Computer
was well equipped to manage this. During the overload, 
the software restart programs allowed only the highest priority jobs 
to be processed— including the programs 
necessary for landing. The Priority Displays 
gave the astronauts a choice— to land or not to land. With minutes to spare, 
Mission Control gave the order. The Apollo 11 landing was about 
the astronauts, Mission Control, software and hardware all working together
as an integrated system of systems. Hamilton’s contributions were essential
to the work of engineers and scientists inspired by President John F. Kennedy’s 
goal to reach the Moon. And her life-saving work 
went far beyond Apollo 11— no bugs were ever found in the in-flight
software for any crewed Apollo missions. After her work on Apollo, Hamilton founded a company that uses 
its unique universal systems language to create breakthroughs 
for systems and software. In 2003, NASA honored her achievements 
with the largest financial award they’d ever given to an individual. And 47 years after her software
first guided astronauts to the moon, Hamilton was awarded 
the Presidential Medal of Freedom for changing the way we think 
about technology.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The _________ would interrupt astronaut’s regularly scheduled tasks to warn them of emergencies. The astronaut could then communicate with Mission Control to determine the best path forward.
Options: A. Altimeter, B. Chronometer, C. Flight Director, D. Priority Displays
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Margaret Hamilton born? Options: A. Indianapolis, Indiana, B. Paoli, Indiana, C. Chicago, Illinois, D. New York City, New York Correct Option: B
Question 2: In what year did Margaret Hamilton receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom? Options: A. 2003, B. 2010, C. 2016, D. Not specified in the transcript Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the primary function of the Priority Displays in the Apollo Guidance Computer? Options: A. To navigate the spacecraft, B. To control the spacecraft's altitude, C. To alert astronauts of emergencies and provide options for response, D. To communicate with Mission Control during routine operations Correct Option: C
Question 4: How did the software developed by Margaret Hamilton's team handle unexpected errors? Options: A. It shut down the system to prevent further damage, B. It quickly detected and recovered from errors in real-time, C. It alerted Mission Control to intervene manually, D. It logged the errors for later analysis Correct Option: B
Question 5: What concept, developed by Margaret Hamilton's team, allowed the Apollo Guidance Computer to manage multiple tasks simultaneously? Options: A. Synchronous programming, B. Asynchronous programming, C. Parallel processing, D. Multitasking Correct Option: B
Question 6: In what field, other than space exploration, could the use of Priority Displays be beneficial? Options: A. Healthcare, B. Finance, C. Education, D. Environmental Science Correct Option: A
Question 7: (Removed, as it is similar to question 6) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why was error-free operation crucial for the Apollo Guidance Computer? Options: A. Because it was a minor aspect of the Apollo 11 mission, B. Because it was a major challenge due to the unreliable computers of the time, C. Because human lives were at stake, D. Because it was required by NASA regulations Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the cause-and-effect connection between the rendezvous radar switch and the overload on the Apollo Guidance Computer? Options: A. The switch caused the AGC to shut down, B. The switch had no effect on the AGC, C. The switch caused the AGC to overload, but the software's fail-safes prevented a failure, D. The switch caused the AGC to malfunction and lose navigation Correct Option: C
Question 10: What could be the result of combining the concepts of asynchronous programming and Priority Displays? Options: A. The development of less efficient systems, B. The creation of more complex and error-prone systems, C. The development of more efficient and adaptable systems, D. The improvement of system reliability but not efficiency Correct Option: C
Question 11: How could the integration of hardware and software teams, as seen in the development of the Apollo Guidance Computer, be beneficial for other complex projects? Options: A. By reducing collaboration and increasing competition between teams, B. By prioritizing hardware development over software development, C. By fostering a more comprehensive understanding of the project's requirements and challenges, D. By streamlining the development process but not improving outcomes Correct Option: C
Question 12: What can be inferred about the impact of Margaret Hamilton's software on the Apollo 11 mission's outcome? Options: A. It had a minor effect on the mission's success, B. It was not a significant factor in the mission's outcome, C. It was essential to the mission's success, D. It contributed to the mission's success but was not essential Correct Option: C
Question 13: What can be concluded about the significance of no bugs being found in the in-flight software for any crewed Apollo missions? Options: A. It was a minor achievement with little significance, B. It was a remarkable achievement that demonstrates the quality of the software development, C. It was only due to luck and chance, D. It was a notable achievement but not a significant factor in the success of the Apollo missions Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 3: What was the primary function of the Priority Displays in the Apollo Guidance Computer? Options: A. To navigate the spacecraft, B. To control the spacecraft's altitude, C. To alert astronauts of emergencies and provide options for response, D. To communicate with Mission Control during routine operations Correct Option: C**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions focus on the function of the Priority Displays, and the correct option (C) in the generated MCQ is similar to the correct option (D) in the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At roughly 4pm on July 20, 1969, mankind was just minutes away 
from landing on the surface of the moon. But before the astronauts 
began their final descent, an emergency alarm lit up. Something was overloading 
the computer, and threatened to abort the landing. Back on Earth, Margaret Hamilton 
held her breath. She'd led the team developing 
the pioneering in-flight software, so she knew this mission 
had no room for error. But the nature 
of this last-second emergency would soon prove her software 
was working exactly as planned. Born 33 years earlier in Paoli, Indiana, 
Hamilton had always been inquisitive. In college, she studied mathematics
and philosophy, before taking a research position at the 
Massachusetts Institute of Technology to pay for grad school. Here, she encountered her first computer
while developing software to support research 
into the new field of chaos theory. Next at MIT's Lincoln Laboratory, Hamilton developed software 
for America’s first air defense system to search for enemy aircraft. But when she heard 
that renowned engineer Charles Draper was looking for help 
sending mankind to the moon, she immediately joined his team. NASA looked to Draper and his group 
of over 400 engineers to invent the first compact 
digital flight computer, the Apollo Guidance Computer. Using input from astronauts, this device would be responsible 
for guiding, navigating and controlling the spacecraft. At a time when unreliable computers 
filled entire rooms, the AGC needed to operate 
without any errors, and fit in one cubic foot of space. Draper divided the lab into two teams, one for designing hardware 
and one for developing software. Hamilton led the team that built 
the on-board flight software for both the Command and Lunar Modules. This work, for which she coined the term
“software engineering," was incredibly high stakes. Human lives were on the line, 
so every program had to be perfect. Margaret’s software needed to quickly
detect unexpected errors and recover from them in real time. But this kind of adaptable program 
was difficult to build, since early software could only process 
jobs in a predetermined order. To solve this problem, Margaret designed her program 
to be “asynchronous,” meaning the software's more important
jobs would interrupt less important ones. Her team assigned every task 
a unique priority to ensure that each job 
occurred in the correct order and at the right time—
regardless of any surprises. After this breakthrough, Margaret realized her software 
could help the astronauts work in an asynchronous environment as well. She designed Priority Displays that would interrupt 
astronaut’s regularly scheduled tasks to warn them of emergencies. The astronaut could then communicate
with Mission Control to determine the best path forward. This marked the first time flight software
communicated directly— and asynchronously— 
with a pilot. It was these fail safes that triggered 
the alarms just before the lunar landing. Buzz Aldrin quickly realized his mistake— he’d inadvertently flipped 
the rendezvous radar switch. This radar would be essential 
on their journey home, but here it was using up 
vital computational resources. Fortunately, the Apollo Guidance Computer
was well equipped to manage this. During the overload, 
the software restart programs allowed only the highest priority jobs 
to be processed— including the programs 
necessary for landing. The Priority Displays 
gave the astronauts a choice— to land or not to land. With minutes to spare, 
Mission Control gave the order. The Apollo 11 landing was about 
the astronauts, Mission Control, software and hardware all working together
as an integrated system of systems. Hamilton’s contributions were essential
to the work of engineers and scientists inspired by President John F. Kennedy’s 
goal to reach the Moon. And her life-saving work 
went far beyond Apollo 11— no bugs were ever found in the in-flight
software for any crewed Apollo missions. After her work on Apollo, Hamilton founded a company that uses 
its unique universal systems language to create breakthroughs 
for systems and software. In 2003, NASA honored her achievements 
with the largest financial award they’d ever given to an individual. And 47 years after her software
first guided astronauts to the moon, Hamilton was awarded 
the Presidential Medal of Freedom for changing the way we think 
about technology.

Options: A. Charles Draper, B. President John F. Kennedy, C. Neil Armontrong, D. Richard Nixon
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A woman in rags emerged from the swamp
flanked by seven giant scorpions. Carrying a baby, she headed 
for the nearest village to beg for food. She approached a magnificent mansion, but the mistress of the house 
took one look at her grimy clothes and unusual companions 
and slammed the door in her face. So she continued down the road 
until she came to a cottage. The woman there took pity on the stranger
and offered her what she could: a simple meal and a bed of straw. Her guest was no ordinary beggar. She was Isis, 
the most powerful goddess in Egypt. Isis was in hiding from her brother Set, who murdered her husband and wanted 
to murder her infant son, Horus. Set was also a powerful god, 
and he was looking for them. So to keep her cover, 
Isis had to be very discreet— she couldn’t risk using her powers. But she was not without aid. Serket, goddess of venomous creatures, had sent seven of her fiercest servants 
to guard Isis and her son. As Isis and Horus settled 
into their humble accommodation, the scorpions fumed at how the wealthy
woman had offended their divine mistress. They all combined their venom 
and gave it to one of the seven, Tefen. In the dead of night, 
Tefen crept over to the mansion. As he crawled under the door, he saw the owner’s young son 
sleeping peacefully and gave him a mighty sting. Isis and her hostess were soon awakened
by loud wailing. As they peered out of the doorway 
of the cottage, they saw a mother running 
through the street, weeping as she cradled her son. When Isis recognized the woman 
who had turned her away, she understood what her 
scorpions had done. Isis took the boy in her arms 
and began to recite a powerful spell: "O poison of Tefen, come out of him 
and fall upon the ground! Poison of Befen, advance not, 
penetrate no farther, come out of him, and fall upon the ground! For I am Isis, the great Enchantress, 
the Speaker of spells. Fall down, O poison of Mestet! 
Hasten not, poison of Mestetef! Rise not, poison of Petet and Thetet! 
Approach not, poison of Matet!" With each name she invoked, 
that scorpion’s poison was neutralized. The child stirred, 
and his mother wept with gratitude and lamented her earlier callousness, offering all her wealth 
to Isis in repentance. The woman who had taken Isis in 
watched in awe— she had had no idea who she’d brought
under her roof. And from that day on, the people learned to make a poultice 
to treat scorpion bites, speaking magical incantations 
just as the goddess had.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where was Isis hiding?
Options: A. Swamp, B. Desert, C. River
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who sent seven scorpions to protect Isis and her son Horus? Options: A. Set, Isis's brother, B. Serket, the goddess of venomous creatures, C. Isis, the most powerful goddess in Egypt, D. Horus, Isis's son Correct Option: B
Question 2: What method did Isis use to save the child from the scorpion's poison? Options: A. A healing potion, B. A powerful spell, C. A magical amulet, D. A sacred ritual Correct Option: B
Question 3: Why did Isis need to be discreet and avoid using her powers? Options: A. To avoid scaring her hostess, B. To avoid detection by Set, C. To avoid revealing her true identity, D. To avoid harming the scorpions Correct Option: B
Question 4: What values are emphasized in the story through the characters' actions? Options: A. Power, wealth, and status, B. Kindness, generosity, and humility, C. Revenge, forgiveness, and justice, D. Loyalty, duty, and obedience Correct Option: B
Question 5: What lesson can be applied to real-life situations from the story? Options: A. The importance of seeking revenge, B. The value of treating others with kindness and respect, C. The power of magical incantations, D. The danger of underestimating others Correct Option: B
Question 6: What can children learn from the story about interacting with others? Options: A. The importance of seeking revenge, B. The value of treating others with kindness and respect, C. The power of magical incantations, D. The danger of making assumptions about others Correct Option: B
Question 7: How does the contrast between the wealthy woman's and the kind woman's actions highlight the importance of certain values? Options: A. The importance of wealth and status, B. The value of kindness and generosity, C. The danger of making assumptions about others, D. The power of magical incantations Correct Option: B
Question 8: What does the story demonstrate about the consequences of one's actions? Options: A. The importance of seeking revenge, B. The consequences of treating others with kindness or cruelty, C. The power of magical incantations, D. The danger of underestimating others Correct Option: B
Question 9: What combination of factors makes Isis and the scorpions a powerful team in the story? Options: A. Isis's magical powers and the scorpions' loyalty, B. Set's power and the wealthy woman's wealth, C. Horus's bravery and the kind woman's generosity, D. Serket's venom and the scorpions' strength Correct Option: A
Question 10: How does the story blend elements of ancient Egyptian mythology and folklore? Options: A. By highlighting the importance of power and wealth, B. By emphasizing the value of kindness, generosity, and humility, C. By demonstrating the power of magical incantations, D. By showcasing the mythology of ancient Egypt Correct Option: B
Question 11: How can the wealthy woman's refusal to help Isis be characterized? Options: A. As admirable and virtuous, B. As callous and selfish, C. As justified and reasonable, D. As a minor mistake Correct Option: B
Question 12: How can Isis's use of magical powers to neutralize the scorpion's poison be characterized? Options: A. As an abuse of power, B. As ineffective and useless, C. As effective and resourceful, D. As a last resort Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

A woman in rags emerged from the swamp
flanked by seven giant scorpions. Carrying a baby, she headed 
for the nearest village to beg for food. She approached a magnificent mansion, but the mistress of the house 
took one look at her grimy clothes and unusual companions 
and slammed the door in her face. So she continued down the road 
until she came to a cottage. The woman there took pity on the stranger
and offered her what she could: a simple meal and a bed of straw. Her guest was no ordinary beggar. She was Isis, 
the most powerful goddess in Egypt. Isis was in hiding from her brother Set, who murdered her husband and wanted 
to murder her infant son, Horus. Set was also a powerful god, 
and he was looking for them. So to keep her cover,

to guard Isis and her son. As Isis and Horus settled 
into their humble accommodation, the scorpions fumed at how the wealthy
woman had offended their divine mistress. They all combined their venom 
and gave it to one of the seven, Tefen. In the dead of night, 
Tefen crept over to the mansion. As he crawled under the door, he saw the owner’s young son 
sleeping peacefully and gave him a mighty sting. Isis and her hostess were soon awakened
by loud wailing. As they peered out of the doorway 
of the cottage, they saw a mother running 
through the street, weeping as she cradled her son. When Isis recognized the woman 
who had turned her away, she understood what her 
scorpions had done. Isis took the boy in her arms 
and began to recite a powerful spell: "O poison of Tefen, come out of him 
and fall upon the ground! Poison of Befen, advance not, 
penetrate no farther, come out of him, and fall upon the ground! For I am Isis, the great Enchantress, 
the Speaker of spells. Fall down, O poison of Mestet! 
Hasten not, poison of Mestetef! Rise not, poison of Petet and Thetet! 
Approach not, poison of Matet!" With each name she invoked, 
that scorpion’s poison was neutralized. The child stirred, 
and his mother wept with gratitude and lamented her earlier callousness, offering all her wealth 
to Isis in repentance. The woman who had taken Isis in 
watched in awe— she had had no idea who she’d brought
under her roof. And from that day on, the people learned to make a poultice 
to treat scorpion bites, speaking magical incantations 
just as the goddess had.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A woman in rags emerged from the swamp
flanked by seven giant scorpions. Carrying a baby, she headed 
for the nearest village to beg for food. She approached a magnificent mansion, but the mistress of the house 
took one look at her grimy clothes and unusual companions 
and slammed the door in her face. So she continued down the road 
until she came to a cottage. The woman there took pity on the stranger
and offered her what she could: a simple meal and a bed of straw. Her guest was no ordinary beggar. She was Isis, 
the most powerful goddess in Egypt. Isis was in hiding from her brother Set, who murdered her husband and wanted 
to murder her infant son, Horus. Set was also a powerful god, 
and he was looking for them. So to keep her cover, 
Isis had to be very discreet— she couldn’t risk using her powers. But she was not without aid. Serket, goddess of venomous creatures, had sent seven of her fiercest servants 
to guard Isis and her son. As Isis and Horus settled 
into their humble accommodation, the scorpions fumed at how the wealthy
woman had offended their divine mistress. They all combined their venom 
and gave it to one of the seven, Tefen. In the dead of night, 
Tefen crept over to the mansion. As he crawled under the door, he saw the owner’s young son 
sleeping peacefully and gave him a mighty sting. Isis and her hostess were soon awakened
by loud wailing. As they peered out of the doorway 
of the cottage, they saw a mother running 
through the street, weeping as she cradled her son. When Isis recognized the woman 
who had turned her away, she understood what her 
scorpions had done. Isis took the boy in her arms 
and began to recite a powerful spell: "O poison of Tefen, come out of him 
and fall upon the ground! Poison of Befen, advance not, 
penetrate no farther, come out of him, and fall upon the ground! For I am Isis, the great Enchantress, 
the Speaker of spells. Fall down, O poison of Mestet! 
Hasten not, poison of Mestetef! Rise not, poison of Petet and Thetet! 
Approach not, poison of Matet!" With each name she invoked, 
that scorpion’s poison was neutralized. The child stirred, 
and his mother wept with gratitude and lamented her earlier callousness, offering all her wealth 
to Isis in repentance. The woman who had taken Isis in 
watched in awe— she had had no idea who she’d brought
under her roof. And from that day on, the people learned to make a poultice 
to treat scorpion bites, speaking magical incantations 
just as the goddess had.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was Serket the goddess of?
Options: A. Harvests, B. Venomous creatures, C. Hospitality
Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
A woman in rags emerged from the swamp
flanked by seven giant scorpions. Carrying a baby, she headed 
for the nearest village to beg for food. She approached a magnificent mansion, but the mistress of the house 
took one look at her grimy clothes and unusual companions 
and slammed the door in her face. So she continued down the road 
until she came to a cottage. The woman there took pity on the stranger
and offered her what she could: a simple meal and a bed of straw. Her guest was no ordinary beggar. She was Isis, 
the most powerful goddess in Egypt. Isis was in hiding from her brother Set, who murdered her husband and wanted 
to murder her infant son, Horus. Set was also a powerful god, 
and he was looking for them. So to keep her cover, 
Isis had to be very discreet— she couldn’t risk using her powers. But she was not without aid. Serket, goddess of venomous creatures, had sent seven of her fiercest servants 
to guard Isis and her son. As Isis and Horus settled 
into their humble accommodation, the scorpions fumed at how the wealthy
woman had offended their divine mistress. They all combined their venom 
and gave it to one of the seven, Tefen. In the dead of night, 
Tefen crept over to the mansion. As he crawled under the door, he saw the owner’s young son 
sleeping peacefully and gave him a mighty sting. Isis and her hostess were soon awakened
by loud wailing. As they peered out of the doorway 
of the cottage, they saw a mother running 
through the street, weeping as she cradled her son. When Isis recognized the woman 
who had turned her away, she understood what her 
scorpions had done. Isis took the boy in her arms 
and began to recite a powerful spell: "O poison of Tefen, come out of him 
and fall upon the ground! Poison of Befen, advance not, 
penetrate no farther, come out of him, and fall upon the ground! For I am Isis, the great Enchantress, 
the Speaker of spells. Fall down, O poison of Mestet! 
Hasten not, poison of Mestetef! Rise not, poison of Petet and Thetet! 
Approach not, poison of Matet!" With each name she invoked, 
that scorpion’s poison was neutralized. The child stirred, 
and his mother wept with gratitude and lamented her earlier callousness, offering all her wealth 
to Isis in repentance. The woman who had taken Isis in 
watched in awe— she had had no idea who she’d brought
under her roof. And from that day on, the people learned to make a poultice 
to treat scorpion bites, speaking magical incantations 
just as the goddess had.

**Transcript**:
A woman in rags emerged from the swamp
flanked by seven giant scorpions. Carrying a baby, she headed 
for the nearest village to beg for food. She approached a magnificent mansion, but the mistress of the house 
took one look at her grimy clothes and unusual companions 
and slammed the door in her face. So she continued down the road 
until she came to a cottage. The woman there took pity on the stranger
and offered her what she could: a simple meal and a bed of straw. Her guest was no ordinary beggar. She was Isis, 
the most powerful goddess in Egypt. Isis was in hiding from her brother Set, who murdered her husband and wanted 
to murder her infant son, Horus. Set was also a powerful god, 
and he was looking for them. So to keep her cover, 
Isis had to be very discreet— she couldn’t risk using her powers. But she was not without aid. Serket, goddess of venomous creatures, had sent seven of her fiercest servants 
to guard Isis and her son. As Isis and Horus settled 
into their humble accommodation, the scorpions fumed at how the wealthy
woman had offended their divine mistress. They all combined their venom 
and gave it to one of the seven, Tefen. In the dead of night, 
Tefen crept over to the mansion. As he crawled under the door, he saw the owner’s young son 
sleeping peacefully and gave him a mighty sting. Isis and her hostess were soon awakened
by loud wailing. As they peered out of the doorway 
of the cottage, they saw a mother running 
through the street, weeping as she cradled her son. When Isis recognized the woman 
who had turned her away, she understood what her 
scorpions had done. Isis took the boy in her arms 
and began to recite a powerful spell: "O poison of Tefen, come out of him 
and fall upon the ground! Poison of Befen, advance not, 
penetrate no farther, come out of him, and fall upon the ground! For I am Isis, the great Enchantress, 
the Speaker of spells. Fall down, O poison of Mestet! 
Hasten not, poison of Mestetef! Rise not, poison of Petet and Thetet! 
Approach not, poison of Matet!" With each name she invoked, 
that scorpion’s poison was neutralized. The child stirred, 
and his mother wept with gratitude and lamented her earlier callousness, offering all her wealth 
to Isis in repentance. The woman who had taken Isis in 
watched in awe— she had had no idea who she’d brought
under her roof. And from that day on, the people learned to make a poultice 
to treat scorpion bites, speaking magical incantations 
just as the goddess had.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 2013, a team of researchers 
held a math test. The exam was administered 
to over 1,100 American adults, and designed, in part, to test 
their ability to evaluate sets of data. Hidden among these math problems 
were two almost identical questions. Both problems 
used the same difficult data set, and each had one objectively 
correct answer. The first asked about the correlation 
between rashes and a new skin cream. The second asked about the correlation 
between crime rates and gun control legislation. Participants with strong math skills were much more likely 
to get the first question correct. But despite being 
mathematically identical, the results for the second question 
looked totally different. Here, math skills 
weren’t the best predictor of which participants answered correctly. Instead, another variable the researchers 
had been tracking came into play: political identity. Participants whose political beliefs aligned with a correct interpretation 
of the data were far more likely 
to answer the problem right. Even the study’s top mathematicians were 45% more likely 
to get the second question wrong when the correct answer 
challenged their political beliefs. What is it about politics that inspires 
this kind of illogical error? Can someone’s political identity 
actually affect their ability to process information? The answer lies in a cognitive phenomenon that has become increasingly visible 
in public life: partisanship. While it’s often invoked 
in the context of politics, partisanship is more broadly defined 
as a strong preference or bias towards any particular group or idea. Our political, ethnic, religious, 
and national identities are all different forms of partisanship. Of course, identifying with social groups is an essential and healthy part 
of human life. Our sense of self is defined not only by 
who we are as individuals, but also by the groups we belong to. As a result, we’re strongly motivated 
to defend our group identities, protecting both our sense of self 
and our social communities. But this becomes a problem 
when the group’s beliefs are at odds with reality. Imagine watching your favorite sports team
commit a serious foul. You know that’s against the rules, but your fellow fans 
think it’s totally acceptable. The tension between 
these two incompatible thoughts is called cognitive dissonance, and most people are driven to resolve 
this uncomfortable state of limbo. You might start to blame the referee, 
complain that the other team started it, or even convince yourself 
there was no foul in the first place. In a case like this, people are often more motivated 
to maintain a positive relationship with their group 
than perceive the world accurately. This behavior 
is especially dangerous in politics. On an individual scale, allegiance to a party allows people 
to create a political identity and support policies they agree with. But partisan-based cognitive dissonance 
can lead people to reject evidence that’s inconsistent with the party line 
or discredits party leaders. And when entire groups of people revise 
the facts in service of partisan beliefs, it can lead to policies 
that aren’t grounded in truth or reason. This problem isn’t new— political identities 
have been around for centuries. But studies show 
that partisan polarization has increased dramatically 
in the last few decades. One theory explaining this increase is the trend towards clustering 
geographically in like-minded communities. Another is the growing tendency 
to rely on partisan news or social media bubbles. These often act like echo chambers, delivering news and ideas 
from people with similar views. Fortunately, cognitive scientists 
have uncovered some strategies for resisting this distortion filter. One is to remember that you’re probably 
more biased than you think. So when you encounter new information, make a deliberate effort 
to push through your initial intuition and evaluate it analytically. In your own groups, try to make 
fact-checking and questioning assumptions a valued part of the culture. Warning people that they might have been 
presented with misinformation can also help. And when you’re trying 
to persuade someone else, affirming their values 
and framing the issue in their language can help make people more receptive. We still have a long way to go before 
solving the problem of partisanship. But hopefully, these tools 
can help keep us better informed, and capable of making evidence-based 
decisions about our shared reality.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In 2013 a team of researchers examined how people solved identical math problems about non-political (skin cream) and political (gun control) topics. Which problems were most difficult for people?
Options: A. Non-political topics, B. Political topics, C. Both were equal
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary objective of the 2013 study that tested over 1,100 American adults? Options: A. To assess the impact of partisanship on cognitive dissonance, B. To evaluate the ability to analyze data sets and solve math problems, C. To investigate the relationship between politics and social media, D. To examine the effects of cognitive dissonance on mental health Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the study, what was a significant predictor of correct answers for the math problem about crime rates and gun control legislation? Options: A. Math skills, B. Political identity, C. Demographic characteristics, D. Prior knowledge of the topic Correct Option: B
Question 3: What does the concept of partisanship refer to in the context of the study? Options: A. A strong preference or bias towards a particular group or idea, B. The ability to evaluate data sets objectively, C. The tendency to reject evidence that contradicts one's own views, D. A neutral or impartial stance on an issue Correct Option: A
Question 4: According to the study, what can lead people to reject evidence that contradicts their party's views or leaders? Options: A. Cognitive dissonance, B. Partisan-based cognitive dissonance, C. Confirmation bias, D. The availability heuristic Correct Option: B
Question 5: How can individuals resist the distortion filter of partisanship when evaluating information? Options: A. By relying solely on intuition and personal opinions, B. By fact-checking and questioning assumptions, C. By ignoring contradictory evidence, D. By seeking out only information that confirms one's own views Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is an essential consideration when evaluating information in various aspects of life, according to the study? Options: A. Considering only one perspective, B. Evaluating information analytically and considering multiple perspectives, C. Relying solely on emotions and personal opinions, D. Ignoring contradictory evidence Correct Option: B
Question 7: What contrast is highlighted by the study regarding people's ability to solve math problems? Options: A. The contrast between people's ability to solve math problems when they are emotionally invested versus when they are not, B. The contrast between people's ability to solve math problems when they are under time pressure versus when they are not, C. The contrast between people's ability to solve math problems when they are in a group versus when they are alone, D. The contrast between people's ability to solve math problems when the correct answer aligns with their political beliefs versus when it does not Correct Option: D
Question 8: What relationship is explored by the study regarding partisanship and cognitive dissonance? Options: A. The relationship between partisanship and the tendency to seek out diverse perspectives, B. The relationship between partisanship and the ability to evaluate data sets objectively, C. The relationship between partisanship and cognitive dissonance, showing how people may prioritize maintaining a positive relationship with their group over perceiving the world accurately, D. The relationship between partisanship and the tendency to reject evidence that contradicts one's own views Correct Option: C
Question 9: How can the study's findings be combined with the concept of cognitive dissonance to understand how partisanship affects people's ability to process information? Options: A. By recognizing that partisanship can lead to cognitive dissonance, which can result in people rejecting evidence that contradicts their party's views, B. By acknowledging that cognitive dissonance is the primary cause of partisanship, C. By understanding that partisanship and cognitive dissonance are unrelated concepts, D. By assuming that people are always able to evaluate information objectively, regardless of their partisan affiliations Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can be developed by combining the strategies for resisting partisanship with the idea of partisanship as a strong preference or bias? Options: A. Effective methods for promoting critical thinking and evidence-based decision-making, B. Strategies for increasing partisan polarization, C. Techniques for manipulating people's opinions, D. Methods for ignoring contradictory evidence Correct Option: A
Question 11: What should be considered when evaluating the study's findings? Options: A. The study's sample size and population, B. The study's data analysis techniques, C. The study's conclusions and implications, D. The validity and reliability of the study's methodology and findings Correct Option: D
Question 12: What should be considered when critiquing the strategies for resisting partisanship? Options: A. Their effectiveness in promoting critical thinking and evidence-based decision-making, B. Their potential limitations and areas for improvement, C. Their ability to eliminate partisan polarization entirely, D. Their potential to increase partisan polarization Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

This question highlights the contrast between people's ability to solve math problems when the correct answer aligns with their political beliefs versus when it does not, which is the main idea of the ground truth MCQ. The options in Question 7 also align with the intent of the ground truth MCQ, which is to examine how people's problem-solving abilities are affected by the political nature of the topic.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 2013, a team of researchers 
held a math test. The exam was administered 
to over 1,100 American adults, and designed, in part, to test 
their ability to evaluate sets of data. Hidden among these math problems 
were two almost identical questions. Both problems 
used the same difficult data set, and each had one objectively 
correct answer. The first asked about the correlation 
between rashes and a new skin cream. The second asked about the correlation 
between crime rates and gun control legislation. Participants with strong math skills were much more likely 
to get the first question correct. But despite being 
mathematically identical, the results for the second question 
looked totally different. Here, math skills 
weren’t the best predictor of which participants answered correctly. Instead, another variable the researchers 
had been tracking came into play: political identity. Participants whose political beliefs aligned with a correct interpretation 
of the data were far more likely 
to answer the problem right. Even the study’s top mathematicians were 45% more likely 
to get the second question wrong when the correct answer 
challenged their political beliefs. What is it about politics that inspires 
this kind of illogical error? Can someone’s political identity 
actually affect their ability to process information? The answer lies in a cognitive phenomenon that has become increasingly visible 
in public life: partisanship. While it’s often invoked 
in the context of politics, partisanship is more broadly defined 
as a strong preference or bias towards any particular group or idea. Our political, ethnic, religious, 
and national identities are all different forms of partisanship. Of course, identifying with social groups is an essential and healthy part 
of human life. Our sense of self is defined not only by 
who we are as individuals, but also by the groups we belong to. As a result, we’re strongly motivated 
to defend our group identities, protecting both our sense of self 
and our social communities. But this becomes a problem 
when the group’s beliefs are at odds with reality. Imagine watching your favorite sports team
commit a serious foul. You know that’s against the rules, but your fellow fans 
think it’s totally acceptable. The tension between 
these two incompatible thoughts is called cognitive dissonance, and most people are driven to resolve 
this uncomfortable state of limbo. You might start to blame the referee, 
complain that the other team started it, or even convince yourself 
there was no foul in the first place. In a case like this, people are often more motivated 
to maintain a positive relationship with their group 
than perceive the world accurately. This behavior 
is especially dangerous in politics. On an individual scale, allegiance to a party allows people 
to create a political identity and support policies they agree with. But partisan-based cognitive dissonance 
can lead people to reject evidence that’s inconsistent with the party line 
or discredits party leaders. And when entire groups of people revise 
the facts in service of partisan beliefs, it can lead to policies 
that aren’t grounded in truth or reason. This problem isn’t new— political identities 
have been around for centuries. But studies show 
that partisan polarization has increased dramatically 
in the last few decades. One theory explaining this increase is the trend towards clustering 
geographically in like-minded communities. Another is the growing tendency 
to rely on partisan news or social media bubbles. These often act like echo chambers, delivering news and ideas 
from people with similar views. Fortunately, cognitive scientists 
have uncovered some strategies for resisting this distortion filter. One is to remember that you’re probably 
more biased than you think. So when you encounter new information, make a deliberate effort 
to push through your initial intuition and evaluate it analytically. In your own groups, try to make 
fact-checking and questioning assumptions a valued part of the culture. Warning people that they might have been 
presented with misinformation can also help. And when you’re trying 
to persuade someone else, affirming their values 
and framing the issue in their language can help make people more receptive. We still have a long way to go before 
solving the problem of partisanship. But hopefully, these tools 
can help keep us better informed, and capable of making evidence-based 
decisions about our shared reality.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is common between sports fans and political partisans?
Options: A. They both love sports, B. Blame the referee, C. They both identify with groups, D. They are both rational
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary objective of the 2013 study that tested over 1,100 American adults? Options: A. To assess the impact of partisanship on cognitive dissonance, B. To evaluate the ability to analyze data sets and solve math problems, C. To investigate the relationship between politics and social media, D. To examine the effects of cognitive dissonance on mental health Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the study, what was a significant predictor of correct answers for the math problem about crime rates and gun control legislation? Options: A. Math skills, B. Political identity, C. Demographic characteristics, D. Prior knowledge of the topic Correct Option: B
Question 3: What does the concept of partisanship refer to in the context of the study? Options: A. A strong preference or bias towards a particular group or idea, B. The ability to evaluate data sets objectively, C. The tendency to reject evidence that contradicts one's own views, D. A neutral or impartial stance on an issue Correct Option: A
Question 4: According to the study, what can lead people to reject evidence that contradicts their party's views or leaders? Options: A. Cognitive dissonance, B. Partisan-based cognitive dissonance, C. Confirmation bias, D. The availability heuristic Correct Option: B
Question 5: How can individuals resist the distortion filter of partisanship when evaluating information? Options: A. By relying solely on intuition and personal opinions, B. By fact-checking and questioning assumptions, C. By ignoring contradictory evidence, D. By seeking out only information that confirms one's own views Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is an essential consideration when evaluating information in various aspects of life, according to the study? Options: A. Considering only one perspective, B. Evaluating information analytically and considering multiple perspectives, C. Relying solely on emotions and personal opinions, D. Ignoring contradictory evidence Correct Option: B
Question 7: What contrast is highlighted by the study regarding people's ability to solve math problems? Options: A. The contrast between people's ability to solve math problems when they are emotionally invested versus when they are not, B. The contrast between people's ability to solve math problems when they are under time pressure versus when they are not, C. The contrast between people's ability to solve math problems when they are in a group versus when they are alone, D. The contrast between people's ability to solve math problems when the correct answer aligns with their political beliefs versus when it does not Correct Option: D
Question 8: What relationship is explored by the study regarding partisanship and cognitive dissonance? Options: A. The relationship between partisanship and the tendency to seek out diverse perspectives, B. The relationship between partisanship and the ability to evaluate data sets objectively, C. The relationship between partisanship and cognitive dissonance, showing how people may prioritize maintaining a positive relationship with their group over perceiving the world accurately, D. The relationship between partisanship and the tendency to reject evidence that contradicts one's own views Correct Option: C
Question 9: How can the study's findings be combined with the concept of cognitive dissonance to understand how partisanship affects people's ability to process information? Options: A. By recognizing that partisanship can lead to cognitive dissonance, which can result in people rejecting evidence that contradicts their party's views, B. By acknowledging that cognitive dissonance is the primary cause of partisanship, C. By understanding that partisanship and cognitive dissonance are unrelated concepts, D. By assuming that people are always able to evaluate information objectively, regardless of their partisan affiliations Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can be developed by combining the strategies for resisting partisanship with the idea of partisanship as a strong preference or bias? Options: A. Effective methods for promoting critical thinking and evidence-based decision-making, B. Strategies for increasing partisan polarization, C. Techniques for manipulating people's opinions, D. Methods for ignoring contradictory evidence Correct Option: A
Question 11: What should be considered when evaluating the study's findings? Options: A. The study's sample size and population, B. The study's data analysis techniques, C. The study's conclusions and implications, D. The validity and reliability of the study's methodology and findings Correct Option: D
Question 12: What should be considered when critiquing the strategies for resisting partisanship? Options: A. Their effectiveness in promoting critical thinking and evidence-based decision-making, B. Their potential limitations and areas for improvement, C. Their ability to eliminate partisan polarization entirely, D. Their potential to increase partisan polarization Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question is about the concept of partisanship, which is related to the idea of identifying with groups, as mentioned in the ground truth MCQ. The correct option in Question 3 (A. A strong preference or bias towards a particular group or idea) is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (C. They both identify with groups). 

Although the questions are not identical, they both touch on the idea of group identity and its relation to partisanship, making Question 3 the most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 2013, a team of researchers 
held a math test. The exam was administered 
to over 1,100 American adults, and designed, in part, to test 
their ability to evaluate sets of data. Hidden among these math problems 
were two almost identical questions. Both problems 
used the same difficult data set, and each had one objectively 
correct answer. The first asked about the correlation 
between rashes and a new skin cream. The second asked about the correlation 
between crime rates and gun control legislation. Participants with strong math skills were much more likely 
to get the first question correct. But despite being 
mathematically identical, the results for the second question 
looked totally different. Here, math skills 
weren’t the best predictor of which participants answered correctly. Instead, another variable the researchers 
had been tracking came into play: political identity. Participants whose political beliefs aligned with a correct interpretation 
of the data were far more likely 
to answer the problem right. Even the study’s top mathematicians were 45% more likely 
to get the second question wrong when the correct answer 
challenged their political beliefs. What is it about politics that inspires 
this kind of illogical error? Can someone’s political identity 
actually affect their ability to process information? The answer lies in a cognitive phenomenon that has become increasingly visible 
in public life: partisanship. While it’s often invoked 
in the context of politics, partisanship is more broadly defined 
as a strong preference or bias towards any particular group or idea. Our political, ethnic, religious, 
and national identities are all different forms of partisanship. Of course, identifying with social groups is an essential and healthy part 
of human life. Our sense of self is defined not only by 
who we are as individuals, but also by the groups we belong to. As a result, we’re strongly motivated 
to defend our group identities, protecting both our sense of self 
and our social communities. But this becomes a problem 
when the group’s beliefs are at odds with reality. Imagine watching your favorite sports team
commit a serious foul. You know that’s against the rules, but your fellow fans 
think it’s totally acceptable. The tension between 
these two incompatible thoughts is called cognitive dissonance, and most people are driven to resolve 
this uncomfortable state of limbo. You might start to blame the referee, 
complain that the other team started it, or even convince yourself 
there was no foul in the first place. In a case like this, people are often more motivated 
to maintain a positive relationship with their group 
than perceive the world accurately. This behavior 
is especially dangerous in politics. On an individual scale, allegiance to a party allows people 
to create a political identity and support policies they agree with. But partisan-based cognitive dissonance 
can lead people to reject evidence that’s inconsistent with the party line 
or discredits party leaders. And when entire groups of people revise 
the facts in service of partisan beliefs, it can lead to policies 
that aren’t grounded in truth or reason. This problem isn’t new— political identities 
have been around for centuries. But studies show 
that partisan polarization has increased dramatically 
in the last few decades. One theory explaining this increase is the trend towards clustering 
geographically in like-minded communities. Another is the growing tendency 
to rely on partisan news or social media bubbles. These often act like echo chambers, delivering news and ideas 
from people with similar views. Fortunately, cognitive scientists 
have uncovered some strategies for resisting this distortion filter. One is to remember that you’re probably 
more biased than you think. So when you encounter new information, make a deliberate effort 
to push through your initial intuition and evaluate it analytically. In your own groups, try to make 
fact-checking and questioning assumptions a valued part of the culture. Warning people that they might have been 
presented with misinformation can also help. And when you’re trying 
to persuade someone else, affirming their values 
and framing the issue in their language can help make people more receptive. We still have a long way to go before 
solving the problem of partisanship. But hopefully, these tools 
can help keep us better informed, and capable of making evidence-based 
decisions about our shared reality.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When your favorite sports team breaks the rules by committing a serious foul against the other team, it can create an uncomfortable feeling called cognitive dissonance. How can you reduce this feeling?
Options: A. Convince yourself there was no foul, B. Blame the referee, C. Assume the other team was an instigator, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

To examine the effects of cognitive dissonance on mental health Correct Option: B

By fact-checking and questioning assumptions, C. By ignoring contradictory evidence, D. By seeking out only information that confirms one's own views Correct Option: B

Evaluating information analytically and considering multiple perspectives, C. Relying solely on emotions and personal opinions, D. Ignoring contradictory evidence Correct Option: B
Question 7: What contrast is highlighted by the study regarding people's ability to solve math problems? Options: A. The contrast between people's ability to solve math problems when they are emotionally invested versus when they are not, B. The contrast between people's ability to solve math problems when they are under time pressure versus when they are not, C. The contrast between people's ability to solve math problems when they are in a group versus when they are alone, D. The relationship between partisanship and the tendency to reject evidence that contradicts one's own views Correct Option: C

By recognizing that partisanship can lead to cognitive dissonance, which can result in people rejecting evidence that contradicts their party's views, B. By acknowledging that cognitive dissonance is the primary cause of partisanship, C. By understanding that partisanship and cognitive dissonance are unrelated concepts, D. By assuming that people are always able to evaluate information objectively, regardless of their partisan affiliations Correct Option: A

Methods for ignoring contradictory evidence Correct Option: A

The study's conclusions and implications, D. The validity and reliability of the study's methodology and findings Correct Option: D

Their potential limitations and areas for improvement, C. Their ability to eliminate partisan polarization entirely, D. Their potential to increase partisan polarization Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 2013, a team of researchers 
held a math test. The exam was administered 
to over 1,100 American adults, and designed, in part, to test 
their ability to evaluate sets of data. Hidden among these math problems 
were two almost identical questions. Both problems 
used the same difficult data set, and each had one objectively 
correct answer. The first asked about the correlation 
between rashes and a new skin cream. The second asked about the correlation 
between crime rates and gun control legislation. Participants with strong math skills were much more likely 
to get the first question correct. But despite being 
mathematically identical, the results for the second question 
looked totally different. Here, math skills 
weren’t the best predictor of which participants answered correctly. Instead, another variable the researchers 
had been tracking came into play: political identity. Participants whose political beliefs aligned with a correct interpretation 
of the data were far more likely 
to answer the problem right. Even the study’s top mathematicians were 45% more likely 
to get the second question wrong when the correct answer 
challenged their political beliefs. What is it about politics that inspires 
this kind of illogical error? Can someone’s political identity 
actually affect their ability to process information? The answer lies in a cognitive phenomenon that has become increasingly visible 
in public life: partisanship. While it’s often invoked 
in the context of politics, partisanship is more broadly defined 
as a strong preference or bias towards any particular group or idea. Our political, ethnic, religious, 
and national identities are all different forms of partisanship. Of course, identifying with social groups is an essential and healthy part 
of human life. Our sense of self is defined not only by 
who we are as individuals, but also by the groups we belong to. As a result, we’re strongly motivated 
to defend our group identities, protecting both our sense of self 
and our social communities. But this becomes a problem 
when the group’s beliefs are at odds with reality. Imagine watching your favorite sports team
commit a serious foul. You know that’s against the rules, but your fellow fans 
think it’s totally acceptable. The tension between 
these two incompatible thoughts is called cognitive dissonance, and most people are driven to resolve 
this uncomfortable state of limbo. You might start to blame the referee, 
complain that the other team started it, or even convince yourself 
there was no foul in the first place. In a case like this, people are often more motivated 
to maintain a positive relationship with their group 
than perceive the world accurately. This behavior 
is especially dangerous in politics. On an individual scale, allegiance to a party allows people 
to create a political identity and support policies they agree with. But partisan-based cognitive dissonance 
can lead people to reject evidence that’s inconsistent with the party line 
or discredits party leaders. And when entire groups of people revise 
the facts in service of partisan beliefs, it can lead to policies 
that aren’t grounded in truth or reason. This problem isn’t new— political identities 
have been around for centuries. But studies show 
that partisan polarization has increased dramatically 
in the last few decades. One theory explaining this increase is the trend towards clustering 
geographically in like-minded communities. Another is the growing tendency 
to rely on partisan news or social media bubbles. These often act like echo chambers, delivering news and ideas 
from people with similar views. Fortunately, cognitive scientists 
have uncovered some strategies for resisting this distortion filter. One is to remember that you’re probably 
more biased than you think. So when you encounter new information, make a deliberate effort 
to push through your initial intuition and evaluate it analytically. In your own groups, try to make 
fact-checking and questioning assumptions a valued part of the culture. Warning people that they might have been 
presented with misinformation can also help. And when you’re trying 
to persuade someone else, affirming their values 
and framing the issue in their language can help make people more receptive. We still have a long way to go before 
solving the problem of partisanship. But hopefully, these tools 
can help keep us better informed, and capable of making evidence-based 
decisions about our shared reality.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How can you help persuade someone from another group?
Options: A. Insult their intelligence, B. Use their language, C. Argue with them, D. Publicly shame them
Correct Option: B

Options: A. By relying solely on intuition and personal opinions, B. By fact-checking and questioning assumptions, C. By ignoring contradictory evidence, D. By seeking out only information that confirms one's own views
